author: jhondesousa

description.text: A rubber band powered PCB vise.

Print two of the end pieces. You can print one set of the pcbvise-support.stl (note: currently untested) or you can use small dowels or pencils through the square holes. Make sure the slots are facing each other. Wrap rubber bands around each end of both dowels to stop the pieces from slipping off or use the (untested) stops in the pcbvise-support.stl file. Then put a large rubber band through the center slot on both pieces. Secure one side around the right hand dowel on both pieces on the outside (non-slot) side of the vise. Then repeat with another rubber band but do the left hand side. If your rubber band is large enough (like the one in the pictures) you may only need one rubber band for all sides. Now you can insert a board in the slots by pulling apart the plates. The rubber bands will pull it back in trapping the board. Based loosely on this design: http://www.qrpbuilder.com/downloads/pcb_holder_you_can_build_102012.pdf My first significant design for 3d printing. I never thought about it, but you could probably use this in a regular vise as well like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11783

title: Doblo Spinny

description.text: Duplo(TM)-compatible bricks with a ball-bearing swivel.  Make a merry-go-round, globe, rotating castle, gun turret, or anything else that wants to turn.

Requires a 608 ball-bearing set (~$0.60 on Amazon and other places if you buy ~10). Tolerances may vary from printer to printer. Print out the bearing_test part to see if as-printed you get something that fits the bearing tolerably well. Then print out a bottom and your choice of top and press-fit the bearing to install. The openSCAD file (requires Thing:2106, the Doblo factory) can produce the parts for the bearing_test, top, and bottom targets by commenting in and out the last lines. Likely adjustments are:
B608_play_outside, B608_play_inside: (more positive numbers give a looser fit on the bearing on the top and bottom half, respectively. Print out the bearing_test part for a more rapid iteration cycle than making the entire block each time.)
top_colrow: (rows and columns of nubs on top)
top_wheel: (if true, cut a circle for the top, otherwise leave square) (I apologize for the crudeness of the code and any residual unused openscad from the development process. I tried adding little latching ears but it just caused the clips to break at the base. Maybe experimenting with latchdistance{in,out} will find a good compromise between breaking the part and having the bearing slip off.)

It is placed around the neck of the bottle, and the cap is screwed on. It has to be tight.
3D collage of Rodin's work

I had quite a few photos of Burghers of Calais from Musee Rodin in Paris. I processed photos with my3dscanner and 123DCatch but the results were equally bad.
To get something useful out of it I combined very fragmented 3D models into 3D collage with SmashTheMesh and made a mold for a gypsum model so I can make it when I get 3D printer.

title: Yet Another Spool Holder Laser Cut

description.text:
I was originally going to cut the Printrbot Spool Stand but it was nowhere close to what I wanted. They are using clip in wood parts to hold the bearings and the bearing are not supported from the inside. Also it doesn't fit 8" spools like the ones Makerbot uses. So this will hold 8" full spools and fully support the weight and spin freely. It also prevents the spool from sliding off and jamming. Another nice feature is that you can tie multiple units side by side without the spools touching. Perfect for multiextrusion or just holding all of your filaments ready to feed into your printer.
makergeeks.com is selling this item on their website without direct attribution (other than a link to this page) or attempted to notify me of it. I fully support open source and understand that this is part of the deal.

This is perfect for 8" spools like the ones that come from MakerBot. Here is a demo video to show how well it spins. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ia_oVRQF5og Cut the pieces out and assemble. It is cut from 1/4 or 5mm birch ply. You will need the following hardware:
4 608zz bearings
8 1/4 washers
4 1/4 x 1" nuts and bolts (or 2&1/2" long bolts to tie units together)
2 M3 22 Nuts and bolts

author: Kraaij

description.text:
This is a 3d printed mini quad designed to be strong and easy to travel with, having arms that can be quickly removed or replaced.
You can see a writeup on it here with some flight videos.
It is designed in OpenSCAD around the Sparky flight controller which is a small flight controller I designed that fits within the body. The forward facing camera is a Mobius and the battery slides in below both of these. This keeps the design slick looking and aerodynamic.
I'm quite happy with the performance (10+ min with 1500mAh) and the resulting videos (e.g. https://vimeo.com/99939830 ) 2014-09-01: uploaded minimal.stl which is a more minimal body component that keeps the flight controller exposed.
I printed the arms and body with 30% infill, 3 shells. Then simply plug the arms into the body and drop one screw through the locking hole to secure each arm. Can be disassembled in a few minutes.

comments.text: I just finished printing it and I'll be ordering the electronics tonight. I really like the design. It's even better than the first quad copter I built with the hobbyking sk540 frame. To keep weight down I am going to attempt to use nylon screws. I may end up using this quad copter more than my DJI Phantom 1.1. If this quad flies as good as it looks I will print another one using carbon fiber reinforced PLA. Again thanks for posting this. This is a great platform to build upon.

title: Sony PCM-M10 Digital Audio Recorder Shock Mount for Tripod

description.text:
This thing is a rubber-band shock mount that holds the recorder and attaches to a standard tripod screw. The rubber band suspension prevents loud thumps due to mechanical coupling when using the recorder's internal microphones. You can also just use it on a table top.
This design allows access to ALL the recorder's controls, switches, and I/Os. The only thing you can't do with the recorder mounted is swap out the batteries.

Print the two STL files- PCM-M10 SMR bolts to the recorder and PCM-M10 SMB bolts to the tripod. I printed using Coex3D ABS on MegaMax using 0.35mm nozzle, 0.25mm first layer and 0.2mm for the rest of the layers. I used 20% infill. No support material is required.
The nut hole fits a stainless steel 1/4-20 nut that measures 11.1 mm between parallel faces and is about 4mm thick. The size in the drawing is 11.3 mm between parallel faces and it fits perfectly when MegaMax prints the SMR file. YMMV. Adjust accordingly.
I designed this in Designspark Mechanical because it very easily creates swoopy rounded edges.
The pictures show a single rubber band to hold the recorder but you may want to use three to improve security (if one breaks your recorder won't fall off the mount). Alternatively, you could use the recorder's lanyard to secure it against falls if a rubber band breaks.
Add some sticky rubber feet to the bottom of the SMB for table top use.

My quest for the largest printable Tippe Top continues. To save materials, I constructed the common hollow Tippe Top. A Tippe Top that uses much less plastic than the original Tippe Top (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37177 ).
Two halves to print, which click together. With stereolithography it should be possible to print this as one piece.

The hollow tippe top can be bought in many places, specifically at science musea. They are cheap ... and small. The original tippe top, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37177, is normally carved/cut from wood, while the hollow tippe top is pressed plastic. Other tipping tops: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45822 DISCLAIMER: I have not tested the LARGE version yet! With a normal 3D printer you will need to print the bottom and top part with exterior support, 100% infill layers around 0.2mm. Remove the support after print, and click the two sides together. If the tippe top is not tipping, smooth the exterior as in the instuction of the normal tippe top. Alternative files:
  • Bottom and top part on one plate to print in one go
  • With stereolithography, you could have a go to print it as one piece. If the top is not too large, and you print with the stem down, printing with exterior support might work also...
  • When you increase the size, the stem needs to be shortened to allow tipping of the larger top. You can do that by removing part of the stem. The files with LARGE already have a short stem, the BOTTOM part is the same
  • I also provide a vertically cut version. I don't like this so much as glueing the two parts is normally obvious (see picture). You should be able to print this without support though

title: Bezel/Clock Fonts and a 41mm Bezel Cap

description.text:
Trimmed down the BMP fonts to only those that would be used on a watch bezel, used the Tbuser framework to create double digit numbers 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, 55, a round pip, a bar, and a triangle.
Attaching an incomplete gen2 watch bezel cap with blank 5min markers.

Use this scad module to make a watch face or fill in numbers on a dive watch bezel, the STL is so you can preview the additional double number fonts I made.
You can actually print the blank bezel cap, there are square marks every 30 degrees for 5min markers, fits 41mm bezel watches like the newer GMT Master, Submariner, etc.
Planning to add the font to the blank watch bezel for a complete watch accessory that will temporarily convert a GMT watch into a dive watch and provide some additional protection.

There is one button for the forward motion and one for reverse.
The second button also doubles as at 'turbo' (I use the term turbo in the broadest sense :-) ) So if you hold the forward button and then press the second button the plunger will move faster. This is handy when you have loaded the syringe with solder paste.

This is a conceptual design illustrating an idea I had to create a drop in replacement large gear for existing wade extruder. The teeth are internal to make the overall area taken up by the driven gear and the pinion gear as small as possible.
Unfortunately, I don't think the teeth are quite right, and I don't think this will fit on a wade extruder using any of the existing chassis mounts.
I am hoping someone else might take this idea forward if there is any way the issues can be solved.
In theory you bolt the mount part to the gear part using M4x16 Sckt Cap screws and Nuts.

description.text: Insulation covers for the 'Melzi' controller board as used on the RepRapPro Mendel.

I made these covers for the controller board because the pcb sitting 4mm above the threaded rod just seemed like an accident waiting to happen. Also, the usb connection seemed a bit slack so I wanted a widget to tie the cable to. The covers can be made from just about any card, wood, plastic etc. I made the base from 3mm MDF and the top from clear acrylic. The top has holes to allow acces to the jumpers and reset button. Get making:
Load the .svg file into your drawing program of choice (I â¤ Inkscape)
Export to your cutter of choice (laser, cnc, plasma etc.) To mount your covers on the board and on the machine you will need some longer (25mm) bolts. You will also need some spacers (8mm) between the top cover and the Melzi board.
I made spacers from cable insulation, nothing fancy. The top cover should sit over terminals and line up with the M3 bolt holes. Next, fit the base cover over the bolts and then attach back to the brackets on the threaded rods. Attach the usb cable and fasten with tie wrap or similar.
Your Rep Rap should now be safer and more handsome too. Share & Enjoy!

title: Carriage Adapter Plate for 3D Printed Linear slide

description.text: This is an adapter plate I made to allow a the Kossel Mini's delta arm carriage to be mounted to jcrochol's printed 3d Linear Slide that KongorillaSJK scaled for Misumi 2020 (https://github.com/kongorillaSJK/recirculating). Note: this is NOT for the carriage_recirculating part, this is the standard carriage part from the Kossel repo!)

This uses M3 screws. For the slide plate to adapter, use very short screws (I think 8mm should be ok - I will update when I have confirmed), or cut any excess sticking out of the adapter plate so it is flush with the side of the plate that mates with the carriage.  
For mounting the carriage to the adapter plate, there are 4 captured nut cavities. I may revise these to accomodate nyloc nuts, but for now standard M3 Nuts. Use 12mm or 14mm screws for the upper mounting and 8 or 10mm for the lower mounting holes.

title: Wii Fitness Balance board replacement feet

description.text:
have you cracked or broken one or more of your balance board's feet? well just print a new one!
ALERT!! PLEASE READ INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE PRINTING

1)print object scaling may be incorrect, final dimensions MUST be
16mm X 61.3mm X 61.3mm or it wont fit.
infill should be 15-20% for added strength. 2)super/hot glue 2 pennies on top of eachother 3)glue both pennies into recess in the middle of the foot (press hard) 4)unscrew cover, remove old foot, insert new one, replace cover 5)DONE! SUGGESTED BUT OPTIONAL, place sticky back rubber furniture pad on bottom of foot for traction
OPTIONAL, place electrical tape over pennies to reduce rattle

description.text:
Finished your Arduino Starter kit and wondering where to go next?
Build a line following robot using an Arduino.
This design includes enough parts that you should be able to reprogram it as a maze-solving robot with no extra parts.
Can't make the parts yourself? I'm here to help.
This thing includes all the DXF files for the laser cut parts and the wiring diagrams. For a complete explanation, please see the related blog posts:
Make it
Program it
For more support, please visit our forums.

For a complete explanation, please see the related blog posts:
Make it
Program it

I spent some time to improve the file. It is a much better drawer knob now. I recommend a Z layer pause and a filament switch to make the autobot stand out. Some of the photos show the old design but you point....
Printed at 0.1mm layer height, 100% infill. I would play around with the size to fit your application. As it is, probably needs to be scaled up some.

title: GoPro Multi Purpose Stand/Float
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When my brother first installed his GoPro on his boat bow, he was worried about whether it would stay in place or not. All of the Floats were to small to protect it from sinking, so he asked if I could come up with something. It needed to not only float the GoPro, but also the base that would likely still be attached in the event of a suction release.
I came up with this multi use design. You can use it as a stand that is extendable from 18cm to 30cm. You can use it as an extension to
extend the camera approx 18cm from the mount. Most of all, it can provide enough displacement to float the entire unit.
When using it as a stand, there is enough distance (when in the shorter setting), to protect the lens from impact should it fall over. This can also provide some additional protection when transporting and setting up.
By printing the float piece NinjaFlex, it satisfied my brothers obsessive worries of a scratch in the boat should it fall off as in most cases, the softer plastic will bounce away rather than marring his new boat.

I printed the float using NinjaFlex (TPE). it is printed at .2mm/layer, with 3 walls, and 15%infill. The Float is 15cm tall.
The extension rod was printed using PLA. It was printed at .1mm, with 3 walls, and 25%infill,
The rod settings were to provide strength, and the float settings were to maximize the water tightness of the piece as well as provide support for the roof bridging (I found NinjaFlex is not very good at that for me)

This is a automated two-axis webcam! It's also called the "Sauron Tower". The Webcam Tower is powered by two 28bjy-48 5V Stepper motors and an Arduino. Arduino source and desktop client (windows) is attached to the source files. My (very simple) software is also capable to make simple Panorama Images. Often you have to edit the "settings.ini"-file to specify something. My printer is a Reprap Prusa. The camera is normally attached and
The Webcam and the stepper motors are buyed from Ebay. if you have any questions about the software or other things, just write me a comment :)

Just print the parts. There is nothing special here. Minimal wall-thickness is 2mm. If you start the Software an "settings.ini"-file will be created and you probably will see a message that its failed to open com connection- that's normal. Close the Software and edit the created "settings.ini"-file and change the value "com=36" to "com="[your com Port] and restart the Software. if you start the Webcam and there is a white image click on "Settings..." and change the codec to "YUY2".
if you found an error, yust write it to the comments.

title: Fully contained padlock, no assembly required, rendered as a solid part

description.text: Designed this padlock as a single part in Solidworks.  My intention was to leave enough space between, what will become the moving parts, for the support material to dissolve away leaving the appropriate tolerances for a functioning assembly.  The keyhole is a generic slot that can be actuated by any thin rectangular device.  It is a quarter turn ccw to open.  There are two catches, one at the base of the hoop and one at the top portion, typical of a "Master" style lock.  I changed the appearance on the housing for clarity of the inside.  I was going to print this out as a school project on the Stratasys but time ran out so I really don't know for sure if it actually works.  Hopefully someone here can print one out and verify it becomes a working, fully contained, assembly.  If it does work I will explore making a version in the same style but one that is actually keyed.  Also have one with an included chain, but didn't want to upload until I can verify the lock works.  If it doesn't work please let me know so I can make the appropriate changes.  Also to add to the description, this was designed to be used with a support removal tank (like the Stratasys 1200es uses to dissolve the support material) otherwise the support material will be trapped in the assembly.  Thanks...Dylan

comments.author: dylan77

comments.text: Sorry, as you can see I'm new to this and didn't realize I "encumbered" anything by selecting what I did.  How exactly did I encumber it?  If it is truly a problem then I suppose I can change it (can it not be printed for personal use??)  I thought I was just protecting it from being printed and sold for profit...please advise...thanks...D
comments.author: dylan77

comments.text:
No problem, everyone was new at one point Dylan77. ;)
When I was setting up echo mail to network bulletin board systems so they could give out free internet email addresses there was no limitation placed on how people could use the messaging service and the service was free. Email was the killer app and since that time it has grown to the point where just about everyone has an email address.
When the coders came up with Apache web server, they didn't limit it either. Today Apache is one of the most stable and robust web servers available.
We are creating reality. The ideas are worked out digitally, printed, refined, modified and printed again.
You can create something and claim it as yours. Yours, yours, yours and all yours! ;) (that was humor) That's your right. As the creator of a digital work you own the intellectual property (IP). How will the object be used. Will it have an impact on the world? Not if the IP is encumbered. If it's all yours, then we are not really sharing, if we are not sharing, why download it, print it and then provide feedback on how it can be improved? That creative energy that I can lend to the project to assist you in making a better widget will be limited, because it will be all yours. So the IP encumbrances have a direct impact on the sharing and collaboration within the community. Open objects will be developed and supported by a far wider array of people and encumbered objects will be neglected by the larger community.
If I see a cool widget with a non-commercial encumbrance on it, can I print it and recoup the cost of materials and time? Can I print it often? At what point am I printing that object and now in violation of the IP encumbrance? Yuk.
If I see a cool widget and then want to incorporate a part of the widget into a new thing, the non-commercial tag means I should not be selling that new thing for a profit. Really? How am I supposed to pay my rent? My electric bill? My food?
When we were deploying the first bulletin boards, many of them did not charge it was simple a passion for the sysops. When the internet started to come into the mainstream those sysops that knew their craft from the BBS's (and learned the skills because of the free exchange of ideas and knowledge; I didn't pay my upstream provider for help to setup the email and I didn't charge the BBS's downstream either) were positioned to create the first generation of ISP's.
Some things Dylan you are going to want to keep the IP for yourself. This is your thing and you are going to create it and sell it and you will reap the rewards of your labor and effort.
Other things that are not so near and dear, should be just released into the creative commons. Let people create. Help them create. It's a way to pay it forward. How much of the internet's infrastructure that you are able to use and benefit from was build and created and shared for free?
With this object you are looking for collaboration and assistance. If I were to provide that assistance then at the end of the process I am left with an object that I cannot use. Why jump in and help? IP encumbrances break down the collaborative nature of open development. To facilitate open development, choose licenses that releases the IP into the creative commons, then sit back and watch as the world takes your idea and creates amazing new things with it.
Kinda wordy, but hope it helps.
cheers

description.text: An easy to use folding spool. I made this because I often use filament that comes in a coil, but when I print with it I prefer to have it loaded onto a spool. Manually winding filament from a loose coil onto a large spool is very tedious and annoying work - I'd much rather be designing and printing stuff instead! So this spool will let you quickly load/unload a normal loose coil of filament for printing. Customizable in case you want to have a larger or smaller spool for other purposes, of if you prefer more spokes than 3. [edit]: Makerbot Customizer is stupid. If you want to make a custom variant of this, then download the scad file and export to STL manually. It should be fairly obvious what needs to be edited at the top of the file in order to customize it.

Print without supports - the only place that should require support already has it included in the model (the underside of the spoke fork and finger) Print one each of the top and base parts - these form the central hub. Print a fork and finger for each spoke of the spool - a total of three each. You will need 3x M3 bolts with nuts (anything 13mm or longer will do), and 9x M3 fender washers. These are used to assemble the fingers onto the forks. A pair of washers are sandwiched between the plastic parts, with a third washer under the head of the bolt (there is an indentation in the plastic finger for it). These washers provide a slight amount of reduced friction, allowing the finger to be rotated when loading/unloading filament (without loosening the nut). You will also need 3x M4 bolts (25mm or longer) with nuts to mount the individual spokes to the central hub, which also holds the whole thing together.

description.text:
I created this for dialing in a 3d printer whether that be a new printer, a new material, or just want to recalibrate your existing printer. I've always had problems printing solid infill vs thin wall parts, but not anymore! Just print with 100% infill, adjust the settings, rinse and repeat. The flow/speed settings are commonly adjustable in real time so that can help once you get on the right track. The thin walls are 0.5mm, 1mm, and 1.5mm respectively. The solid part is 15mm x 20mm. This also reveals some printer limitations (mainly the frailty of the 0.5mm wall and layer bonding strength) that you can understand and take advantage off in future designs.
Some tips:
  • If the extruder is making a clicking noise, you are trying to push too much material through the nozzle too fast. Reduce the speed, flow, or both.
  • Make >1 loops/perimeters. This lets you gauge the closeness of the loops to adjust your extrusion width.
  • Extrusion width is NOT your nozzle diameter. As far as I can see, it can't really be measured. If the loops have a small gap between them, try reducing the width and vise-versa if they are overlapping.
  • You won't be able to accurately gauge the flow (you can get good starting ballpark settings though) for the first ~10 or so layers as you will see so don't rely on the lower levels for the entire calibration.
  • Adjustments to height for good first layer adhesion can be more precise than 0.1mm and sometimes require it. Try 0.05mm/0.01mm adjustments and watch your printer interface software to see if it shows the finer Z values.

This fan is just an experiment and is not intended for long term operations. It moves a decent amount of air but slightly vibrates due to improper alignment and a lack of bearings. I'd like to find a way to alleviate these problems without resorting to any vitamins. The dimensions are in no way optimized for maximum airflow. All fan characteristics were implemented based on countless model simulations done in my head using highly advanced guesstimate techniques. I may of also been distracted by the latest episode of The Walking Dead while performing these specialized simulations. If you are interested in actual Centrifugal Fan design, check out these PDF's:
http://www.wesellfans.com/pdf/underStanding-Centrifugal-Fans.pdf http://www.ijaet.org/media/0001/5PARAMETRIC-STUDY-OF-CENTRIFUGAL-FAN-PERFORMANCE-EXPERIMENTS-AND-NUMERICAL-SIMULATION-Copyright-IJAET.pdf

When printing the parts only generate support for the Fan Case.  The necessary support for the Fan Blade is already generated in the .stl file.
I recommend that you print the case in PLA.  The walls suffer from warping when using ABS due to how thin and high they are.  You can see these effects in my photos.
You will need an appropriate sized motor.  The one that I used was just randomly found and has no markings.  
When you first turn it on, check that the Fan Blade is rotating counter-clockwise.  If not, simply reverse the leads.

description.text: A cookie cutter I made with inkscape and openscad

Another one of those left field requests you get from the kids..
I give them free reign on the printer in the school holidays, I am merely the driver :) My daughter wanted to create a bowling set for her Littlest Petshop toys, demands were 2 colour and small, no taller than 3cm, so that was the print I did with the 10 pins, print took 100 minutes.
notes
If printing only 1, I suggest going slow, there isnt alot of raft on a single pin. If printing 10, I packed them on the plate very close so they share a raft, it makes the print much more reliable.

A duct for the power supply fan on a Mendelmax 2.0 3D printer.

The duct just clips into the misumi extrusion.

Print both pieces, glue together, clip into printer.

description.text:
This is a replacement part I designed for a friend of mine.   
It fits a Panasonic NN-ST657W microwave oven. The outer diameter of the ring is 255mm and can accept plastic wheels of 6mm inner diameter. I used the original wheels off the original broken part.  
You will need to print 3 of these and join them together. I placed 2 parts together and melted just using a lighter and then smoothing the parts together until they cooled and became solid. Very strong joint.  
As for the wheels, I placed the plastic wheel over the rod and melted the rod with a cigarette lighter and then pushed the plastic so as to deform it in a way that would stop the wheel from coming off but still allow it to spin.

I printed this on my Flashforge Dreamer with the following: ABS
100% infill
0.3mm layer height
90mm/s
ABS @ 235C
Bed @105C I printed 3 of these to make a complete 255mm circle. Join the parts by melting and then squishing together. So far the part has been put in use in the microwave for up to 10 minutes non-stop and produces no smell and the part is still cold after 10 minutes. I'm not sure how PLA would go?

comments.text: I've been wondering if PLA or ABS are microwave safe.  No problems?
comments.author: sprior

comments.text: I'm not 100% sure but after 10 minutes in the microwave the ABS was still cold and no bad smells.

title: RPi-microscope for histology with focus-drive and XY stage

description.text:
Note: Any tips will go straight to our charity "TReND in Africa" (www.trendinafrica.org) which is dedicated to fostering university level science education on the African continent! Simple framework to hold a histology sample above a Raspberry-Pi (RPi) camera fitted with an acrylic lens to generate a half-descent, low cost microscope. Shown in the images is a brain-slice from rat focussed on the hippocampus and a piece of 3D printing garbage. "Magnification", with a large screen as shown, is in the order of x100.
/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
CHECK OUT OUR SCIENCE IN AFRICA NGO:
TReND in Africa gUG: http://trendinafrica.org/
A registered charity run by volunteer scientists on 4 continents
Help us design good, affordable lab equipment for African scientists!
http://trendinafrica.org/activities/open-source/open-source-main/
Join us! Sponsor us! Spread the word. Thank you! Also, check out our dedicated lab.equipment tinkering page: http://open-labware.net
/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
The idea is pretty similar to my "phone-scope (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280004)" - but image quality is much better (as the RPi camera is great for macro) and here I have a proper focus drive as well as XY-table. A raspberry pi costs about 30$ and the camera another 10$ - so it's a quite cheap solution for a simple, yet half-descent microscope (e.g. for teaching).
Note: Acrylic lense does, like basically any plastic, filter UV. So in principle it should be possible to get fluorescent images out of this by using a strong UV-LED and hope for the best in terms of UV filtering with the lens. If this doesn't work ( I havent tried) try adding some cheap sunglasses, or indeed any odd bit of plastic under the sample for extra UV filtering.

For lenses, see the phone-scope (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280004).
For instructions how to fit continuous rotation servos if required (like this one could turn this into a fouuly automatic 3 axis control system) see my manipulator (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239105). Here you also find detailed instructions how to assemble the manipulator part.
The LED shown can be driven by the GPIO ports of the RPi if required - it's quite simple to do if you know some basic python or have used an Arduino before - it's very similar. I have a silly little python script that controls both the RPi camera and an LED - msg me if interested (but you are probably better off writing your own if you know what you are doing, mine really is very silly indeed)

Was playing with another lofting profile in C4D, the twisted star. Looks like a saw blade to me.
All printed in Taulman 618 nylon and dyed different colors. I printed all the larger vessels on a 1/4" piece of poplar wood as the build surface heated to 60 degrees. Perfect adhesion and easy release. Wood is good!
The little one was printed on our Sailfish-running Thing-o-Matic in the new 1.75mm Taulman 618. I have a spring-loaded idler on an MK7 and had no problems at all with accelerated printing at 60mm/sec. Printed on masking tape and it stuck fine, though I do recommend wood for larger prints. As usual, Sailfish just rocks and the print is absolutely beautiful, hence all the close ups.
Print with zero infill and as many perimeters as you want.  No top layers.  I just stopped the Thing-o-Matic print at the end before it could start bridging.

comments.text: In Slic3r you can shut off the top solid layers before you slice the model.  Not sure about Makerware.  With skeinforge and RepG all I know how to do is turn the printer off when it starts to bridge or edit the top layers out of the gcode.
comments.author: dudgeon

comments.text: In Skeinforge you can disable the 'fill' module, and it will just generate the edges but not the top or bottom. For example, the "stretchy bracelet" is really a squiggly disk - if you don't disable the 'fill' module you end up with a very odd hockey puck. Disabling fill eliminates infill, including top and bottom, so the resulting vases would not be too useful.
comments.author: BenitoSanduchi

comments.text:
Thanks, laird. It will be nice if/when skeinforge has an option for this also.
There are a few reasons why I don't post these things as vessels to begin with.
First, since layer width changes with layer height and nozzle diameter, allowing the slicing program to trace the outline of a solid object produces a more consistant and perfectly solid wall in my experience. On these vases, for example, modeling in the wall thickness cold very easily end up with slic3r deciding it has to put a tiny blob of infill on every single sharp angle if it determines that there will be a gap there due to the layer width.
And then there's file size and slicing time. If you've ever tried to slice a pre-walled vessel or bracelet you know what I mean. Takes forever comparatively.
Lastly, it leaves the number of perimeters up to the individual. A well-calibrated printer can usually pull of single walled prints, but not so if there's z-wobble. Or if there are overhangs that don't require support but do require multiple perimeters, you can figure out what works best for your set-up.
You probably know all that already, laird, but just in case people are wondering why I (and many others) always post solid models to be printed hollow. Seems counterintuitive, but for now, seems to be the best way to go.

author: akeko

title: Ord Bot Z screw Isolator (Wobble Suppressor)

description.text:
Inspired by DaleDunn's elegant solution for z wobble on the Prusa (Thing 20147), I designed a version for the Ord Bot Hadron. This should also work on the Quantum assuming there's enough clearance. There are two versions: One uses the z nuts that came with the Ord Bot Kit and the other uses M8 nuts. A plastic washer might be needed between the two parts to minimize change in z height due to bent threaded rods. Update: The upper piece was too long and it was hitting the z endstop switch on the gantry. So, I deleted the bad files and uploaded the modified files. 1/8/2013
Photo shows comparison of 20mm square x 100 mm tall single wall print with the wobble suppressor (left) and without (right). There was significant z screw wobble with rigid metal Ord Bot z coupler used in this test. 1/9/2013
The remaining z wobble was due to friction between one of the z nut holders and the post. After sanding it down to allow them to slide freely, z wobble was completely eliminated as shown on the photo.

Print the test stl file first to make sure that the slot on the z nut holder fits snugly around the post on the mating gantry support reduce z backlash. If needed, you should be able to tweak the clearance using the extrusion multiplier parameter slic3r.
The mounting holes in the z nut holder are meant to be tapped with M5 threads.

description.text: This is a complement of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32372 so that the contact of the switch leveler is on a flat part of the Ultimaker Z stage.

My very first thing!
I made it to hold a 3W Led star and to attach a 13x13mm heatsink to the back. The holes are a little tight, but that shouldn't be a problem.

The holes on the sides of the star are supposed to be 3mm. It took a while before Slic3r was able to put a full circle inside given my 0.3mm nozzle.
The space between the legs is there to place a small heatsink at the back. I'll be using a relativly high 13x13mm version sticking it with just a drop of cooling paste.
Printed using standard K8200 settings, no infill, 0.3mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer height. As i'm using a mirror, I raised the heatbed temp to 60 degrees.

comments.text: I'll be using the tall version of the Zalman ZM-RHS1 heatsink set, as I still have a bunch of them from the old days.
